rangees.data: No normative values in the literature

content.subtitle: Subject positioning
text: Subject seated facing the examiner, upper limb placed on the examination surface
The examination of the humeroradial joint will begin here with the anterior approach, which requires the subject's elbow to be in full extension
For more comfort, the examination surface (e.g., adjustable height electric table) can be raised, and a pillow can be placed under the subject's elbow
For the lateral aspect of the humeroradial joint, place the subject's elbow in slight flexion[2]

content.subtitle: Anatomical landmarks and palpation
text: Locate and palpate the radial head and the (lateral) epicondyle of the humerus
To confirm that it is indeed the radial head, you can ask the subject to perform some pronation-supination movements while palpating the radial head

vues.title: Longitudinal View
positionnement: In longitudinal view (parallel to the long axis of the forearm), place the proximal end of the probe proximal to the radial head, in the lateral third of the elbow
Still in longitudinal view, place the proximal end of the probe on the (lateral) epicondyle of the humerus

imagePositionnement.descriptionText: Probe position, anterior approach, longitudinal view
Probe position, lateral approach, longitudinal view

texte: The humeral capitulum appears in the lower left portion of the image. It can be recognized by its semi-circular relief, as well as by its proximal location to the adjacent joint space
The radius, which is visible to the right of the humerus, has a profile clearly defined by a hyperechoic line that allows clear distinction of the shaft, neck, and head of the radius
The radial head is the most proximal segment (leftmost) of the radius, just to the right of the joint space that separates the humeral capitulum from the radius.
The humerus appears in the upper left portion of the image as an area bounded upward by a curved hyperechoic line, and to the right by the joint space.
The lateral epicondyle is the convex end of the lateral aspect of the distal humerus.
The radius is visible to the right of the humerus as a vast area bounded upward by a curved hyperechoic line.
The radial head is the most proximal portion (to the left) of the radius, and has a convex profile clearly visible in this image.

The extensor tendons are visible here superficial to the humeral head. Their fibrillar echotexture can be observed, as well as the presence of constituent fibers with heterogeneous echotexture, suggesting belonging to different muscles.

vues.title: Transverse View
objectifs: Observation of the annular ligament of the elbow
positionnement: Rotate the probe 90Â° from the longitudinal view (anterior approach)

texte: The radial head is visible as a large circular hyperechoic area in the center of the image
The annular ligament, a thin hyperechoic layer that follows the contour of the radial head, is visible here in the upper right quadrant of the radial head.

The brachioradialis is located in the upper right portion of the image. It can be recognized by its typical muscular echotexture (when the probe is oriented perpendicular to the fiber direction) and by its location at the anterolateral aspect of the radial head.

text: The humeroradial joint is one of the three joints that make up the elbow complex, along with the humeroulnar joint and the proximal radioulnar joint. It is a modified ball-and-socket joint that allows two degrees of freedom: flexion-extension and pronation-supination.

The articular surfaces consist of the humeral capitulum, which is convex and spherical, and the concave radial fossa of the radial head. The joint is stabilized by several structures, including the annular ligament, which wraps around the radial head and maintains its contact with the ulna during pronation-supination movements.

The lateral collateral ligament complex also contributes to joint stability, particularly during varus stress. The joint capsule encompasses all three joints of the elbow complex and contains synovial fluid that lubricates the articular surfaces and provides nutrition to the articular cartilage.

content.subtitle: Radial head fractures
text: Radial head fractures are common elbow injuries, often resulting from a fall on an outstretched hand. They account for approximately one-third of all elbow fractures. The Mason classification system categorizes these fractures into four types:
Type I: Non-displaced fractures
Type II: Displaced partial articular fractures
Type III: Comminuted fractures involving the entire radial head
Type IV: Radial head fracture with associated elbow dislocation
Ultrasound can be useful in detecting joint effusion and assessing the integrity of surrounding soft tissues, although CT or MRI is typically needed for detailed fracture characterization.

content.subtitle: Osteoarthritis
text: Humeroradial joint osteoarthritis can develop following trauma (particularly after radial head fractures) or as part of primary osteoarthritis affecting the entire elbow. Ultrasound findings may include:
Osteophyte formation at the joint margins
Joint space narrowing
Synovial thickening
Joint effusion
Increased vascularity on power Doppler in cases of active inflammation

content.subtitle: Posterolateral rotatory instability
text: This condition involves dysfunction of the lateral collateral ligament complex and can affect the stability of the humeroradial joint. Dynamic ultrasound examination can be valuable in assessing the integrity of the lateral ligamentous structures and detecting abnormal joint motion.

The European Society of Musculoskeletal Radiology recommends ultrasound as a first-line imaging modality for assessing lateral elbow instability, with a grade 2 consensus level, indicating that ultrasound provides significant diagnostic information, although other imaging modalities may sometimes be necessary for complete evaluation.
